snippet: Employer stock in 401(k) plans is less common than it used to be, but it’s still in plenty of them, including the plan at RadioShack, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month.
abstract: Ron Lieber Your Money column questions why companies allow and encourage employees to invest in company stock as part of their 401(k) plans, despite high-profile examples of employees losing a lot money by doing so, latest of which is RadioShack; warns against practice, and suggests ways employees can insulate themselves from losses.
lead_paragraph: Employer stock in 401(k) plans is less common than it used to be, but it’s still in plenty of them, including the plan at RadioShack, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month.

headline.print_headline: The Scariest Stock to Put in the 401(k)
headline.main: A Scary Movie: Filling Your 401(k) With Company Stock
